front.title: Content ID header field in Session Initiation Protocol (SIP)

abstract.t: This document specifies the Content-ID header field for usage in the Session Initiation Protocol (SIP).

section.title: Identifying a body part
section.t: A SIP message consists of a start-line, one or more header fields, an empty line indicating the end of the header fields, and an optional message-body, as specified in .
The message-body of the SIP message can be a non-multipart body or a multipart body as specified in .
A multipart body contains zero, one or several body parts, encoded using format.
A body part in the multipart body can contain a Content-ID header field with an ID value uniquely identifying the body part, as specified in .

There is no defined method how to convey an ID value uniquely identifying the non-multipart body. The Content-ID header field is not a defined SIP header field and the non-multipart body is not a body part.

section.title: Referencing a body part
section.t: A SIP header field can contain a reference to a body part using a Content-ID URL, as specified in .
The Content-ID URL is specified in . also specifies how to discover the body part referenced by a Content-ID URL.

section.title: Problem statement
section.t:
Since the Content-ID header field is not a defined SIP header field and since non-multipart body is not a body part:
When solely one content needs to be transported in a SIP message, if a UAC does not need to include in the SIP message a SIP header field referencing a body part containing the content, then the UAC can set the message-body to a non-multiparty body containing the content.
However, when solely one content needs to be transported in a SIP message, if a UAC needs to include in the SIP message a SIP header field referencing a body part containing the content, then the UAC needs to set the message-body to a multiparty body with one body part such that the body part contains the content and associated Content-ID header field.

section.title: Example 1
section.t: If a UAC sends an INVITE request conveying location as specified in , if the UAC decides not to include an SDP offer, and if the location is conveyed by value, then the UAC needs to include only one content in the INVITE request.
This content contains the location information and can be e.g. of the application/pidf+xml MIME type.

However, due to requiring inclusion of a Geolocation header field referencing the body part with the content containing the location information, the UAC needs to set the message-body of the INVITE request to a multipart body, and the UAC needs to include a body part with a content of the application/pidf+xml MIME type and with an associated Content-ID header field in the multipart body.

section.title: Example 2
section.t: If a UAC sends an REFER request including a list of targets as specified in , then the UAC needs to include only one content in the REFER request.
This content contains the list of targets and is of the application/resource-lists+xml MIME type.

However, due to requiring inclusion of a Refer-To header field referencing the body part containing the list of targets, the UAC needs to set the message-body of the REFER request to a multipart body, and the UAC needs to include a body part with a content of the application/resource-lists+xml MIME type and with an associated Content-ID header field in the multipart body.

section.title: Solution
section.t: The Content-ID header field included in the header fields of a SIP message identifies a body part consisting of the message-body of a SIP message and metadata provided by some additional SIP header fields.

section.title: Conventions
section.t: The key words "MUST", "MUST NOT", "REQUIRED", "SHALL", "SHALL NOT", "SHOULD", "SHOULD NOT", "RECOMMENDED", "MAY", and "OPTIONAL" in this document are to be interpreted as described in .

section.title: Introduction
section.t: This section defines the usage of the Content-ID header field for SIP.

section.title: Syntax
section.t: The ABNF for the Content-ID header fields is:

figure.artwork:
Content-ID = "Content-ID" HCOLON msg-id
msg-id = "<" id-left "@" id-right ">"
NOTE: id-left and id-right are specified in [RFC5322].
NOTE: When used in a SIP header field, the msg-id syntax has been simplified compared to the syntax in [RFC5322].

section.title: Semantics
section.t: The Content-ID header field can be included in any SIP message which is allowed to contain a message-body.

section.title: UA procedures
section.t: A UA MAY include a Content-ID header field in any SIP message which is allowed to contain a message-body.
A UA MUST NOT include a Content-ID header field in any SIP message which is not allowed to contain a message-body.
The UA MUST set the value of the Content-ID header field to a globally unique value.

section.title: Proxy procedures
section.t: A proxy MUST NOT add a Content-ID header field in a SIP message.
A proxy MUST NOT modify a Content-ID header field included in a SIP message.
A proxy MUST NOT delete a Content-ID header field from a SIP message.

section.title: Security considerations
section.t: The Content-ID header field value MUST NOT reveal sensitive user information.

If the message-body associated with the Content-ID header field contains encrypted content, it MUST NOT be possible to derive a key that can be used to decrypt the message-body content from the Content-ID header field value.
